title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Meconium plug syndrome is a condition that predominantly affects preterm-neonates of low birth weight. It presents with an inability to pass meconium within the first 24 to 48 hours of life, and It must be properly differentiated from similar conditions. As it presents with obstruction, it must be treated accordingly and swiftly. This activity reviews the clinical presentation, diagnosis, treatment, of meconium plug syndrome, and highlights the interdepartmental communication and coordination between pediatricians and other care providers who treat these neonates.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Identify the etiology of meconium plug syndrome and its related conditions. Review the steps in the evaluation of meconium plug syndrome with specific importance to radiological diagnosis. Summarize the management options available for meconium plug syndrome specifically the conservative and surgical options. Describe interprofessional team strategies for improving care coordination and communication particularly among pediatricians of different specialties treating meconium plug syndrome and improve outcomes. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Introduction
content: Meconium plug syndrome causes functional obstruction in the colon of neonates. [1] It occurs relatively commonly in healthy infants (1 in 500 live births). There is a clinical similarity to distal intestinal obstruction presenting with an inability to pass meconium within 24 to 48 hours following delivery. However, several other clinical entities present similarly, both clinically and radiographically. [1] It was initially reported in 1956 by Clatworty to describe colonic obstruction caused by inspissated meconium. [2] There is an association with Hirschsprung disease of approximately 3% to 38%. [3] [4] [5]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Introduction. Meconium plug syndrome causes functional obstruction in the colon of neonates. [1] It occurs relatively commonly in healthy infants (1 in 500 live births). There is a clinical similarity to distal intestinal obstruction presenting with an inability to pass meconium within 24 to 48 hours following delivery. However, several other clinical entities present similarly, both clinically and radiographically. [1] It was initially reported in 1956 by Clatworty to describe colonic obstruction caused by inspissated meconium. [2] There is an association with Hirschsprung disease of approximately 3% to 38%. [3] [4] [5]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Etiology
content: The exact etiology of meconium plug syndrome is ill-defined. In a majority of cases, meconium plug syndrome occurs in isolation. There may be an association, however, with the following conditions: Prematurity Neonates of mothers with diabetes - (gestational diabetes mellitus and chronic diabetes mellitus) Neonates of mothers  who received magnesium sulfate as a treatment for eclampsia or preterm labor
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Etiology. The exact etiology of meconium plug syndrome is ill-defined. In a majority of cases, meconium plug syndrome occurs in isolation. There may be an association, however, with the following conditions: Prematurity Neonates of mothers with diabetes - (gestational diabetes mellitus and chronic diabetes mellitus) Neonates of mothers  who received magnesium sulfate as a treatment for eclampsia or preterm labor

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Moreover, according to a recent study, by Cuenca et al., an association with magnesium tocolysis was noted in 16% of the cases and only 3.2 % with Hirschsprung disease. [6] There is also significant clinical overlap with small left colon syndrome. [6] [5] While the historical association of meconium plug syndrome and Hirschsprung disease has been unclear in some recent studies, other studies demonstrate that meconium plug syndrome (MPS) has an association with Hirschsprung disease (HSCR) in 13 to 38% of patients. [7] [6] [7] [4]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Etiology. Moreover, according to a recent study, by Cuenca et al., an association with magnesium tocolysis was noted in 16% of the cases and only 3.2 % with Hirschsprung disease. [6] There is also significant clinical overlap with small left colon syndrome. [6] [5] While the historical association of meconium plug syndrome and Hirschsprung disease has been unclear in some recent studies, other studies demonstrate that meconium plug syndrome (MPS) has an association with Hirschsprung disease (HSCR) in 13 to 38% of patients. [7] [6] [7] [4]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Epidemiology
content: Meconium plug syndrome is not associated with sex. However, a higher incidence is seen in premature infants, infants of diabetic mothers, and mothers who receive tocolytic drugs. Furthermore, historically, meconium plug syndrome is associated with Hirschsprung disease and cystic fibrosis. [8] There is also a greater incidence in infants with a higher probability of cerebral insult. [9] There have been no reports of increased prevalence in a specific race, ethnic group, or geographical population.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Epidemiology. Meconium plug syndrome is not associated with sex. However, a higher incidence is seen in premature infants, infants of diabetic mothers, and mothers who receive tocolytic drugs. Furthermore, historically, meconium plug syndrome is associated with Hirschsprung disease and cystic fibrosis. [8] There is also a greater incidence in infants with a higher probability of cerebral insult. [9] There have been no reports of increased prevalence in a specific race, ethnic group, or geographical population.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pathophysiology
content: The exact pathogenesis is unknown. The most commonly accepted hypothesis is that meconium plug syndrome is a transient functional colonic immaturity specifically of the myenteric nervous system. Consequently, peristalsis is ineffectual, and therefore the meconium remains in the colon for a more extended period, leading to higher water absorption and the development of meconium plugs that cause obstruction.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pathophysiology. The exact pathogenesis is unknown. The most commonly accepted hypothesis is that meconium plug syndrome is a transient functional colonic immaturity specifically of the myenteric nervous system. Consequently, peristalsis is ineffectual, and therefore the meconium remains in the colon for a more extended period, leading to higher water absorption and the development of meconium plugs that cause obstruction.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pathophysiology
content: In diabetic mothers, the higher occurrence of neonatal hypoglycemia induces the pancreas to secrete glucagon. In turn, glucagon decreases peristalsis in the left colon. Furthermore, neonatal hypoglycemia stimulates the autonomic nervous system. Increased stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system causes a decrease in intestinal movement, which accelerates the development of meconium plugs.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pathophysiology. In diabetic mothers, the higher occurrence of neonatal hypoglycemia induces the pancreas to secrete glucagon. In turn, glucagon decreases peristalsis in the left colon. Furthermore, neonatal hypoglycemia stimulates the autonomic nervous system. Increased stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system causes a decrease in intestinal movement, which accelerates the development of meconium plugs.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- History and Physical
content: The defining presentation of meconium plug syndrome is the inability to pass meconium within the first 24 to 48 hours of life. Subsequently, infants develop abdominal distension and vomiting. The vomiting can present with bilious emesis. Neonates often exhibit with a softly distended abdomen, occasionally with palpable intestinal loops. [5] Nasogastric aspiration yields bilious content—the clinical scenario that of distal intestinal obstruction.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- History and Physical. The defining presentation of meconium plug syndrome is the inability to pass meconium within the first 24 to 48 hours of life. Subsequently, infants develop abdominal distension and vomiting. The vomiting can present with bilious emesis. Neonates often exhibit with a softly distended abdomen, occasionally with palpable intestinal loops. [5] Nasogastric aspiration yields bilious content—the clinical scenario that of distal intestinal obstruction.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation
content: Abdominal plain films are non-specific in the majority of cases. Crosstable or lateral imaging may demonstrate multiple air-fluid levels. However, plain abdominal films cannot distinguish with high specificity the difference between small and large bowel obstruction. Rarely, if there is any air in the rectum, may there be an outline of the meconium mas on an abdominal radiograph. The abdominal film may also demonstrate small bowel gas mixed with colonic meconium producing a granular appearance similar to necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). When a granular pattern occurs within the first 12 hours, the diagnosis is most likely meconium plug syndrome, as NEC develops after >18 hours. [10] In contrast to meconium ileus, meconium plug syndrome radiographs do not demonstrate microcolon. Contrast Enema is the investigation of choice and is often diagnostic and therapeutic.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation. Abdominal plain films are non-specific in the majority of cases. Crosstable or lateral imaging may demonstrate multiple air-fluid levels. However, plain abdominal films cannot distinguish with high specificity the difference between small and large bowel obstruction. Rarely, if there is any air in the rectum, may there be an outline of the meconium mas on an abdominal radiograph. The abdominal film may also demonstrate small bowel gas mixed with colonic meconium producing a granular appearance similar to necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). When a granular pattern occurs within the first 12 hours, the diagnosis is most likely meconium plug syndrome, as NEC develops after >18 hours. [10] In contrast to meconium ileus, meconium plug syndrome radiographs do not demonstrate microcolon. Contrast Enema is the investigation of choice and is often diagnostic and therapeutic.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation
content: The contrast enema, demonstrates the classical visualization of the meconium against the colonic wall, creating a double-contrast impression. [10] [9] Water-soluble contrast is the agent of choice, as barium based contrast agents have a risk of causing peritonitis in case of perforation during the study. Chloride sweat test - to rule out cystic fibrosis. [6]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation. The contrast enema, demonstrates the classical visualization of the meconium against the colonic wall, creating a double-contrast impression. [10] [9] Water-soluble contrast is the agent of choice, as barium based contrast agents have a risk of causing peritonitis in case of perforation during the study. Chloride sweat test - to rule out cystic fibrosis. [6]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation
content: Suction rectal biopsy - to rule out Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the rectal biopsy specimen. In 13 to 38% of cases, meconium plug syndrome (MPS) has correlations with Hirschsprung disease (HD). [4] Serum electrolytes - To monitor the infant's electrolyte status during treatment with contrast enema agents.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Evaluation. Suction rectal biopsy - to rule out Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the rectal biopsy specimen. In 13 to 38% of cases, meconium plug syndrome (MPS) has correlations with Hirschsprung disease (HD). [4] Serum electrolytes - To monitor the infant's electrolyte status during treatment with contrast enema agents.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management
content: Treatment is predominantly non-surgical. The primary motive is to stimulate the rectum or colon by using a water-soluble contrast enema. Some patients might require serial enemas, possibly using acetylcysteine. [9] Most of the cases respond immediately to the enema, with the instant passage of stools and cessation of abdominal distension.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management. Treatment is predominantly non-surgical. The primary motive is to stimulate the rectum or colon by using a water-soluble contrast enema. Some patients might require serial enemas, possibly using acetylcysteine. [9] Most of the cases respond immediately to the enema, with the instant passage of stools and cessation of abdominal distension.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management
content: If there is no passage of stools by 48 to 72 hours, surgical options may be a consideration. A suction rectal biopsy should be performed. Additionally, if temporary decompression of the bowel is necessary, a temporary ileostomy is performed. Additional surgical approaches include the Mikulicz double-barreled ileostomy, which has a zero risk of an intraabdominal anastomosis whereas the aesthetically pleasing option is a skin bridge temporary ileostomy.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management. If there is no passage of stools by 48 to 72 hours, surgical options may be a consideration. A suction rectal biopsy should be performed. Additionally, if temporary decompression of the bowel is necessary, a temporary ileostomy is performed. Additional surgical approaches include the Mikulicz double-barreled ileostomy, which has a zero risk of an intraabdominal anastomosis whereas the aesthetically pleasing option is a skin bridge temporary ileostomy.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management
content: More advanced options include a distal ileostomy with a Bishop-Koop anastomosis ( end to side ileal)- known as distal chimney enterostomy and a similar proximal chimney enterostomy called the Santulli procedure. Usually, ten days following the surgery, the enterostomies can be closed by performing an end-to-end anastomosis. [11]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Treatment / Management. More advanced options include a distal ileostomy with a Bishop-Koop anastomosis ( end to side ileal)- known as distal chimney enterostomy and a similar proximal chimney enterostomy called the Santulli procedure. Usually, ten days following the surgery, the enterostomies can be closed by performing an end-to-end anastomosis. [11]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Diagnosis of meconium plug syndrome (MPS) is a challenge because several other clinical entities present similarly. The differential diagnosis includes Hirschsprung disease, malrotation, meconium disease, and intestinal atresia. The major conditions that should be ruled out are listed below:
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Diagnosis of meconium plug syndrome (MPS) is a challenge because several other clinical entities present similarly. The differential diagnosis includes Hirschsprung disease, malrotation, meconium disease, and intestinal atresia. The major conditions that should be ruled out are listed below:

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Meconium ileus: Here, the inspissated meconium obstructs the small intestine rather than the colon and decreases the diameter of the colon, resulting in a microcolon.  In comparison, meconium ileus is a disease of critical nature as it has a higher rate of complications such as perforation, small bowel volvulus, peritonitis, and intestinal atresia and strong association with cystic fibrosis. [12]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Meconium ileus: Here, the inspissated meconium obstructs the small intestine rather than the colon and decreases the diameter of the colon, resulting in a microcolon.  In comparison, meconium ileus is a disease of critical nature as it has a higher rate of complications such as perforation, small bowel volvulus, peritonitis, and intestinal atresia and strong association with cystic fibrosis. [12]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Small left colon syndrome(SLCS): Historically considered along with meconium plug syndrome as both are transient functional obstructions of the colon. SLCS characteristically presents a sudden change in the colonic diameter proximal to the splenic flexure. MPS occurs mostly in preterms, whereas SLCS occurs in full-term babies. A majority of both MPS and SLCS patients revert to normal spontaneously within 30 days. [13]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Small left colon syndrome(SLCS): Historically considered along with meconium plug syndrome as both are transient functional obstructions of the colon. SLCS characteristically presents a sudden change in the colonic diameter proximal to the splenic flexure. MPS occurs mostly in preterms, whereas SLCS occurs in full-term babies. A majority of both MPS and SLCS patients revert to normal spontaneously within 30 days. [13]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Hirschsprung disease: the absence of ganglion cells can be differentiated on rectal biopsy.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Hirschsprung disease: the absence of ganglion cells can be differentiated on rectal biopsy.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Anorectal malformations: diagnosed by physical exam.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Anorectal malformations: diagnosed by physical exam.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Malrotation: limited upper gastrointestinal contrast study to evaluate for malrotation.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Intestinal atresia: upper and lower gastrointestinal series
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Intestinal atresia: upper and lower gastrointestinal series

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Prognosis
content: Meconium Plug Syndrome usually has an excellent prognosis. While a significant proportion of cases resolve spontaneously, almost all cases respond to water-soluble contrast enema, provided the absence of other underlying diseases. It is a relatively being condition that may resolve spontaneously or with contrast enema.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Prognosis. Meconium Plug Syndrome usually has an excellent prognosis. While a significant proportion of cases resolve spontaneously, almost all cases respond to water-soluble contrast enema, provided the absence of other underlying diseases. It is a relatively being condition that may resolve spontaneously or with contrast enema.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Prognosis
content: Meconium plug syndrome has links with diseases such as Hirschsprung diseases and cystic fibrosis. However, there is a wide range of reported incidence in the literature, and some of this may occur from institutional definitions and potential miscoding. [3]
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Prognosis. Meconium plug syndrome has links with diseases such as Hirschsprung diseases and cystic fibrosis. However, there is a wide range of reported incidence in the literature, and some of this may occur from institutional definitions and potential miscoding. [3]

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Complications
content: Almost all cases resolve with conservative treatment and rare ones might need surgery. The surgical outcome is also excellent. However, rare complications include bowel perforation, necrosis of the bowel, meconium peritonitis.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Complications. Almost all cases resolve with conservative treatment and rare ones might need surgery. The surgical outcome is also excellent. However, rare complications include bowel perforation, necrosis of the bowel, meconium peritonitis.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: Parents require education on the normal passage of meconium and its's importance. Furthermore, parents might need to look out for potential warning signs such as abdominal distension and refusal of feeds.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Deterrence and Patient Education. Parents require education on the normal passage of meconium and its's importance. Furthermore, parents might need to look out for potential warning signs such as abdominal distension and refusal of feeds.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pearls and Other Issues
content: Meconium plug syndrome is a functional disorder of the colon, which is a separate entity from neonatal small left colon syndrome. It requires differentiation from other causes of non-passage of meconium to ensure swift treatment. Treatment is conservative and relatively successful in a large majority of the cases. There is an association with Hirschsprung disease, which should be pursued with suction rectal biopsy if there is no passage of stool following contrast enema or return of bowel function.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Pearls and Other Issues. Meconium plug syndrome is a functional disorder of the colon, which is a separate entity from neonatal small left colon syndrome. It requires differentiation from other causes of non-passage of meconium to ensure swift treatment. Treatment is conservative and relatively successful in a large majority of the cases. There is an association with Hirschsprung disease, which should be pursued with suction rectal biopsy if there is no passage of stool following contrast enema or return of bowel function.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Meconium plug syndrome is a condition that often responds to conservative treatment, should be swiftly recognized and treated. However, several other potentially more critical disorders present similarly in the neonate with the inability to pass meconium within 24 to 48 hours of birth. As a result, interpersonal communication is of paramount importance between the parent - in case the child is handed over to the parents or the neonatal care nurse - in case the child is in the care of a neonatal inpatient unit. Prompt recognition of clinical signs like abdominal distension, bilious vomiting could lead to timely execution of treatment and better clinical outcomes.

However, several other potentially more critical disorders present similarly in the neonate with the inability to pass meconium within 24 to 48 hours of birth. As a result, interpersonal communication is of paramount importance between the parent - in case the child is handed over to the parents or the neonatal care nurse - in case the child is in the care of a neonatal inpatient unit. Prompt recognition of clinical signs like abdominal distension, bilious vomiting could lead to timely execution of treatment and better clinical outcomes.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: It presents a diagnostic dilemma as radiologically, as it is challenging to diagnose by using abdominal plain film and requires a contrast enema to diagnose. Therefore, proper interdepartmental communication between the radiologist and the consulting pediatrician can result in a swift diagnosis and earlier scheduling of contrast enemas.
contents: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes. It presents a diagnostic dilemma as radiologically, as it is challenging to diagnose by using abdominal plain film and requires a contrast enema to diagnose. Therefore, proper interdepartmental communication between the radiologist and the consulting pediatrician can result in a swift diagnosis and earlier scheduling of contrast enemas.

title: Meconium Plug Syndrome -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: The pediatric gastroenterologist may also be called upon to perform contrast enemas and rectal biopsies, while a pediatric anesthetist might be required to anesthetize the baby and monitor it during the procedure. A pediatric surgeon may be necessary to consult for ongoing bowel obstruction or perforation or to perform the rectal biopsy. A geneticist can help to rule out cystic fibrosis. Interprofessional coordination between nurses, nursing practitioners, anesthetists, neonatal care workers is also necessary to properly coordinate neonatal care.

Interprofessional coordination between nurses, nursing practitioners, anesthetists, neonatal care workers is also necessary to properly coordinate neonatal care.
